titleStmt.title: Physician specialty and long-term survival after myocardial infarction -A study including all German statutory health insured patients

affiliation.orgName: National Association of Statutory Health Insurance Physicians

analytic.title: Physician specialty and long-term survival after myocardial infarction -A study including all German statutory health insured patients

biblStruct.note: Received 21 June 2017 Received in revised form 25 September 2017 Accepted 13 October 2017

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: Myocardial infarction Ambulatory care Cardiologist Mortality Medical claims data

p.s: Background: With a mortality rate above European average, myocardial infarction (MI) is the second most common cause of death in Germany.
Data about post-MI ambulatory care and mortality is scarce.
We examined the association between ambulatory treating physicians' specialty and the mortality of post-MI patients.
Methods: Medical claims data of all 17 German regional Associations of Statutory Health Insurance physicians were analyzed, which cover approximately 90% of the German population.
Patients with a new diagnosis of a MI in 2011 were divided into treatment groups with and without ambulant cardiology care within the first year after MI diagnosis.
Propensity-score matching based on socio-demographic and clinical variables was performed to achieve comparability between groups.
The 18-month mortality rate was derived employing a validated method.
Results: 158,494 patients with a new diagnosis of MI had received post-MI ambulatory care in 2011.
Half of them (51%) had at least one ambulatory contact with a cardiologist within the first year.

During a follow-up of 18 months, the mortality rate before and after propensity-score matching was 19% and 14% in patients without cardiology care and 6%, respectively, in patients with cardiology care (χ 2 = 666.7;
P b 0.000 after propensity adjustment).
Patients who only saw a cardiologist and had no additional contact to an ambulant general practitioner (GP)/internist within the first year did not have increased survival rates.
Conclusions: Outpatient follow-up care by a cardiologist in combination with consultations of GP/internists within the first year may be of importance for the prognosis of MI patients.
Myocardial infarction (MI) is the second most common cause of death in Germany [1].
In recent years, MI incidence and mortality rates have declined [2][3][4][5][6] due to combined effects of prevention, progress in therapy and improved guideline-based care of patients [7].
Still, the German MI mortality rates are above the European Union's average [8].
After a MI, 24% of patients die immediately or on the way to the hospital [9] and 9% of those who get to the hospital alive die in-hospital [10].
About 20% of patients aged 75 and older die within one year after being discharged from hospital in Germany [11].
International studies report mortality rates of around 11% within one year, 21% within three years and 33% within five years after hospital discharge [12,13].

In-hospital clinical management as well as a variety of biological, socio-economic and behavioral patient characteristics have been associated with differences in the short and longer-term mortality for MI [14][15][16][17].
European guidelines for the long-term management of post-MI patients focus on the rigorous control of cardiac risk factors [18,19].
Less attention has been paid to the role of the physicians who provide care after a MI.
Studies have shown that the treating physicians' specialty in-hospital might play an important role for the prognosis of a patient.
Patients who were treated by cardiologists had lower mortality rates in comparison to patients who were treated by other internists or general practitioners (GP) [20][21][22][23][24].
However, the treating physician's specialty might also be important in the post-MI aftercare in the outpatient sector.
In an US-American study, Ayanian et al. investigated 35,520 elderly Medicare patients (aged 65 to 84 year) after hospitalization for MI in 1994 or 1995.
They showed that patients who had visited an ambulant cardiologist had a significantly reduced two year mortality compared to patients who only consulted an internist or GP [25].
Most other studies reporting on differences between generalist and specialist care have been published in the United States and examined the in-hospital time and short-term survival of patients.

A possible association of the specialty of the ambulatory treating physician with long-term mortality has not been studied recently, and to our knowledge, no such analysis has been performed in Europe.

Germany in particular has a healthcare system that offers a unique opportunity for the analysis of specialist care impact, since it provides access to GP care and specialist care for all insured patients, regardless of their insurance company, age, employment or socioeconomic situation.

We used medical claims data of all patients with statutory health insurance (SHI) in Germany (90% of the population) to assess the number of patients post MI who received care in the outpatient sector in 2011.

Controlling for potential differences in comorbidities and smoking, we tested whether patients who had at least one ambulatory care visit to a cardiologist had different 18-month survival rates in comparison to patients who did not receive ambulatory care by a cardiologist at all.
Analyses were carried out using Germany-wide ambulatory medical claims data [26] of the National Association of SHI Physicians for the period of 2009 until June 2015.
Data was available for all persons insured in a SHI in 2011, which applies to about 90% of the population in Germany, approximately 70 million persons.

The claims data contains individual pseudonymised information on the patient (age, gender, regional-code), diseases as encoded diagnoses (International Classification of Diseases (ICD-10)), and information about the ambulatory healthcare (participating physician, medical indication, invoiced procedures, treatment costs) on a quarterly basis.
Individuals were included in the study if they were given a new diagnosis of MI in 2011 (ICD-10: I21, I22) coded as 'confirmed' or 'state after' from an ambulatory physician.

Patients were excluded from the study if they had earlier been diagnosed with a MI, if no or no plausible information was available for age, gender, or type of district and if they had not had contact to an ambulant GP, internist or cardiologist within the first year after the diagnosis of MI.

For the main analysis of the follow-up care within the first year, we divided patients into two groups: 1) patients without ambulatory cardiology care and 2) patients who at least once consulted an ambulant cardiologist.
Patients were followed from the quarter in 2011 of their first ambulatory diagnosis of MI until the end of June 2015.

For each eligible patient, information was extracted from the database on demographics (age, gender, regional-code by the time of their first ambulatory MI diagnosis), secondary diagnoses (ICD-10 encoded), ambulatory medical treatments and the number of visits to different outpatient physicians.
Based on the regional-code, the patients were assigned to different types of districts: big cities, urban counties, rural counties (showing densification), and sparsely populated rural counties [27].
In our analysis we included all comorbidities and diagnoses that were identified from literature as being independent risk factors for a higher mortality rate.
Further diagnoses of interest were those showing a significant difference between the two patient groups one year before the diagnosis of MI.
The diagnoses had to be coded as 'confirmed' or 'state after' from any ambulatory physician within six quarters preceding or subsequent to the first diagnosis of MI.
Individual patient baseline morbidity level at baseline was assessed using the Charlson Comorbidity Index (CCI) [28,29].
The CCI is a widely used measure of comorbidity, developed to predict 1-year mortality in a cohort of medical inpatients [28].

An overall score with a maximum of 29 points is calculated from a list of 17 conditions, each of which has been allocated a weight between one and six based upon its adjusted relative risk of 1-year mortality [28,29].
The individual scores were calculated on the basis of whether a particular condition was present as 'confirmed' within the preceding six quarters before the initial MI diagnosis.
See the Supplemental Material for a list of specific ICD-10 codes that have been used.
As MI was the condition of interest in this study, it was not included in the calculation of the CCI score.
Since the medical claims data do not contain information on the death of a patient, an identification method was developed and validated using an existing German insurance sample.
This insurance sample is a subsample of 20% of insured persons based on medical claims data and is representative for all insured persons in SHI in Germany [30].
It is validated and crosschecked by the insurance companies.
Within the insurance sample, the physicians' treatments and diagnoses are recorded as well as the insured person's death [31].
Therefore, this sample provides the basic information to verify the validity of our methods to identify deceased persons in the larger medical claims database.
To identify the death of a patient in the data used for analysis, the following steps were taken: patients with MI in 2011 were identified and two observation periods were defined.
The first period is the ambulant post-MI-period in 2011, beginning with the quarter of the MI diagnosis.
The second period is a control-period in which the survival status of each patient is assessed, covering the years 2012-2013.

If a patient did not have at least one ambulatory care contact to any ambulatory physician during the two year control-period, it was assumed that he or she was deceased during the post-MI-period in 2011.
This procedure was then applied to the data of the insurance sample.

After applying of the methodology with a two year control period to check whether the patient is still alive, followed by matching it with the actual deceased variable which is available in the insurance sample, 99.3% of the patients were classified correctly and 0.7% of the patients were classified incorrectly.
This validated deceased-methodology was subsequently applied to the patients with MI in the full data set.
Since the medical claims data are available until June 2015, both observation periods were extended.
The post-MI-period was extended up to six quarters (18 months), beginning with the quarter of the MI diagnosis.
This observation period has the same length for every patient to be able to compare them with each other.
The ensuing control period to check the survival of patients was extended to a minimum of two years, ending for all patients with the end of June 2015.

To classify a patient as 'survived' in the 18-month 'ambulant post-MI-period', the patient had to have at least one ambulatory visit to any SHI physician during the individual subsequent two up to three year control period.
If this was not the case, the patient was marked as 'deceased'.
Based on the described results of the validation of this method within the insurance sample as well as the extended observation period, it is assumed that the misclassification bias is below 1%.
We used nearest neighbor propensity-score matching to ensure that the two patientgroups, with and without cardiology care, were comparable in terms of patient characteristics.
The propensity-score was estimated by the use of all listed variables and the CCI score in Table 1 [32][33][34].
Based on the calculated score, every patient of the group with cardiology care was matched to the closest patient of the group without cardiology care.
Furthermore, the propensity-score's tolerable deviation of each match was defined in advance with a Caliper ("maximum distance"), therefore consequently excluding bad matches with high differences.
The Caliper was set at c = 0.00001 * propensity-score's standard deviation, which reduced the difference between the groups by N95% [35] .
Continuous variables are presented as mean values and standard deviation (SD); categorical variables as frequency counts and percentages.
We used χ 2 test in the unmatched and McNemar's test for paired data in the matched data to evaluate the differences in 18-month-mortality among the compared groups.
A bilateral probability threshold of 0.05 was used to determine statistical significance.
After patient matching for each gender and type of district we calculated the relative risk (RR) and RR reduction in mortality.
All statistical analyses were performed using the statistics software R, matching was performed using the packages "MatchIt" [36] and "RItools" [37].
170,806 patients with a new diagnosis of MI in 2011 were enrolled in the data analysis, 12,312 patients were excluded after applying the exclusion criteria (Fig. 1).
In total 158,494 patients were included in the main analysis.
Baseline characteristics for the study sample, divided into the groups with and without contact to a cardiologist within the first year are presented in Table 1.
The mean age of all patients was 69 years (±13.4),
63% were men.

About half of the patients (51%) had at least one contact with an ambulant cardiologist during the first year; slightly more patients in the former western states of Germany (52%) compared to the former eastern states (49%).
Further aspects of analysis did not show relevant differences regarding results from former eastern or western parts of Germany.
More men consulted a cardiologist (55%) in comparison to women (44%).

The proportion of patients who received cardiology care was highest in big cities with a total of 55% (men: 59% vs. women: 48%), decreased with the level of urbanization to 52% (57% vs. 45%) in urban counties, to 47% (51% vs. 40%) in rural counties, to the lowest proportion of 46% (50% vs. 39%) in sparsely populated rural counties.
A total of 12% died within the 18-month follow-up (men: 11% vs. women: 15%).
The proportion of deceased patients during the 18-month follow-up period was three times higher in the group without cardiology care (19%) than in the group with cardiology care (6%).

The patient groups with and without cardiology care also differed in the proportion of comorbidities and other diagnoses and the CCI score Characteristics of patients with a newly diagnosed MI in 2011 who received ambulatory cardiology care within the first year of treatment and patients who did not, before and after matching.
Patients were matched according to their estimated propensity-score to visit a cardiologist.
The absolute difference and 95% CI refer to the differences between the patients' groups.
MI, myocardial infarction; SD, standard deviation; CI, confidence intervals.
(Table 1).
We applied propensity-score matching for group comparability.
Altogether, 40,074 patients could be matched, with each resulting group containing 20,037 patients.
After matching the overall χ 2 test over all variables showed no significance between the groups (P = 0.455).
The standardized difference could be reduced from 18% before matching to 0.9% after [35].
Gender, age, place of residence, cardiac and non-cardiac diagnoses, overall medical comorbidity as well as the proportion of smokers were equally distributed in the matched groups (Table 1).
The proportion of patients marked as deceased in the group without cardiology care decreased after matching from 19% to 14%; and remained equal at 6% in the group with cardiology care (Fig. 2a).

In the unmatched sample, patients with cardiology care had a reduced mortality of 71% during the 18-month follow-up compared to patients without cardiology care (RR 0.29; CI: 0.28; 0.30); after matching, the reduction in mortality was 56% (RR 0.44; CI: 0.41; 0.47).
Results were similar after further subdivision by type of district.
The proportions of patients marked as deceased in the unmatched study population were between 12% and 13%.
Upon further subdivision by gender the deceased's proportion was highest among women in sparsely populated rural counties with 16%.
A new matching with a Caliper of c = 0.0001 per type of district and gender was performed on patients with and without cardiology care.
The following overall Chi-square test was not significant for any of the eight subgroups (all P N 0.584).
The matching showed that contact to a cardiologist had a protective impact for both men and women in each type of district and reduced the RR of mortality up to 60%.
Women in sparsely populated rural counties had a slightly lower RR reduction in mortality when they had contact to a cardiologist than the other matched groups (RR 0.52; CI: 0.38; 0.71) (Table 2).

div.head: Number of quarterly visits to cardiologists and GP/internists

p.s: We assessed the frequency of visits to cardiologists and GP/internists on a quarterly basis in all survived patients.
Nearly half of the patients with cardiology care (44%) went to see a cardiologist in only one quarter during the follow-up-year.
For half of all these patients (55%), it was the first quarter in which the MI diagnosis was encoded.
There were no noticeable differences with regard to gender or district.
Patients with and without cardiology care consulted a GP/internist on an equitable basis, 95% in each group in 3 out of 4 quarters.
Further subdivision by gender and type of district showed no difference in GP/ internist visits.

Counting all physician specialties, patients with cardiology care had a higher number of quarterly physician contacts in comparison to patients without cardiology care (mean number of contacts in the first quarter of the follow-up year: 4.4 ± 2.5 in patients with cardiology care vs. 3.7 ± 2.3 in patients without cardiology care).

To rule out the possibility that an increase in physician contacts accounted for the survival benefit of patients with cardiology care, we analyzed the relation between number of quarterly physician contacts and mortality.
In both matched groups (patients with and without cardiology care) increased quarterly physician contacts were not associated with higher survival rates.
On the contrary, there was a trend for higher mortality rates in patients with a higher number of physician contacts (data not shown).
Thus, increased physician contacts did not account for the survival benefit of patients with cardiology care.

Further analysis: 18-month mortality in a patient group with sole contact to a cardiologist and a group without any visit to a GP/internist or cardiologist 1282 patients from the original data of 158,494 MI patients had solely contact to a cardiologist and had no additional contact to an ambulant GP/internist within the first year.
12% of those patients were marked as deceased during the follow-up period (men: 13% vs. women: 10%).

After performing another propensity-score matching, the number of deceased in the group with solely contact to a cardiologist did not differ significantly from the number of deceased in the group without cardiology care (proportion of deceased: 13.2% vs. 12.4%; χ 2 = 0.291; P = 0.589) (Fig. 2b).
Patients who had not visited a cardiologist or a GP/internist in 2011 were excluded from the analyses (n = 1041) (Fig. 1).
For these patients, the MI diagnosis had been provided by other ambulatory care physicians (e.g.
nephrologist, urologist or ophthalmologists).
Of these, 324 (31%) had been marked as deceased within 18 months, of which 69% (n = 225) had their last ambulatory contact within the first quarter year of the post-MI observation period.
We conducted the first nationwide analysis of ambulatory care of patients after a new diagnosis of MI, with complete data of around 90% of the German population.

The results of our large study, including almost 160,000 patients with MI, suggest a lower mortality risk in patients who received ambulatory cardiology care within the first year after MI diagnosis in comparison to patients who did not receive ambulatory cardiology care.
These findings are in line with results from studies in other countries and studies examining the impact of physician specialty in hospital-care settings [20][21][22][23][24][25].
We used medical claims data for the analyses.
By excluding patients with MI episodes in the two previous years, we avoided the potential bias of mixing incident and recurrent MI patients.
The determined number of 158,494 ambulatory MI patients corresponds well with reports from German in-hospital MI cases.
In 2011, 218,253 cases were reported of which 20,251 died in in-hospital [10].
Only half of the patients in our sample consulted a cardiologist during the first year.

The reasons why patients did not see a cardiologist might be diverse and could include individual patient characteristics [24], a possible cardiologist follow-up-treatment in-hospital (which we were not able to assess with our data), an ongoing rehabilitation, trust in the GP or difficulties in the access to specialists.
In a German survey, N30% of the interviewed persons in rural districts stated that they were discontented with the access to specialists [38].
Women in rural districts in particular had the lowest rates of seeing an ambulatory cardiologist (39%), possibly reflecting restriction in mobility [39] .

According to the European guideline for the treatment of coronary artery disease, the therapeutic goals are the reduction of cardiovascular morbidity, in particular the prevention of (new) MI, as well as the improvement of the prognosis for the patient [40,41].
Visits should be to the GP who may refer to the cardiologist in case of uncertainty [40].

The German guideline for the treatment of coronary artery disease goes beyond that recommendation and states explicitly that an acute coronary syndrome (including MI) dating back less than a year, should be treated jointly by a GP and cardiologist [41].
Our data supports this recommendation.

Public policy makers should support this collaboration through appropriate means, for example, through physician incentives, patient empowerment, by improving access to specialist care in underserved regions, and by allocating resources to improving the gap between hospital and ambulatory care.
Our findings are in line with the recommendations of the guidelines [40,41] that the treatment should be carried out together by a GP and a cardiologist.
The sole contact to a cardiologist without visits to a GP/ internist does not increase the survival rates, only the collaboration between them.
An additional analysis of patients who did not visit a cardiologist or a GP/internist at all showed that this group had the highest mortality rates.
Nearly 70% of them had their last ambulatory physician visit within the quarter of the MI diagnosis, which suggests that they had died early.
Also, this group may have been hospitalized for the majority of days in that quarter and not have had a chance for a GP/internist/cardiologist visit.
The main strength of our study is that it entails the entire population insured in SHI, covering around 90% of the entire German population.
It is the largest and most comprehensive analysis of ambulatory care after diagnosis of MI in Germany so far.
The long term monitoring of diseases and their treatment are major advantages of these data [42].

In addition to what is known from US-American studies, we showed that combined GP and specialist cardiology care was associated with a survival benefit in areas with a high, as well as areas with a low density of specialist care providers.
This finding, together with the equal care principle for all SH-insured persons in Germany, offers more robust support for the importance of specialist cardiology care after MI.
Several limitations apply.
Medical claims data are secondary data, generated for billing purpose by SHI physicians.
The claims data do not contain additional information about the patient besides general characteristics, diagnoses and treatments as described by the billing codes.

Therefore, we were unable to control for factors like social status, education, occupation, treatment preferences, medication or severity of diagnoses, which could have further impact on the survival of a patient [24].

Unfortunately, the billing codes for cardiological services in our medical claims data differ for GP and cardiologist and also do not allow differentiating, what exact procedures were performed on the patient.
We were not able to identify the one or (more likely) the combination of reasons that cause the observed effect.
By means of propensity-score matching, we created a control group that was comparable to the patients with cardiology care with respect to influential variables.
Nearest-neighbor-matching complemented with a Caliper is particularly suited to create controls with minimal Patient matching was performed separately for each type of district and gender.
The Relative Risk (RR) and 95% CI refer to the difference between the patient groups regarding the frequency of patients marked as deceased.
CI, confidence intervals; RR, relative risk.
bias [43].
Matching methods have proved to be suitable for simulating the results of a randomized research design in retrospective evaluations [42].
But, they are not a substitute for randomization [44].

And, unlike randomization, propensity score methods only ensure balance in measured and not unmeasured or hidden confounders [44,45] However, an unmeasured confounder would have to be unrelated to all the variables we used and also be correlated with the visit to a cardiologist and the outcome mortality to relevantly influence the presented observations.
Since we had no proven information about the death of a patient within the claims data, we worked with a newly developed methodology to identify and mark these patients.
With this method, 99% of patients could be classified correctly using an insurance sample for validation.

In addition, the long-term mortality rates in our study were similar to one other German study which included 154 German hospitals with 2045 patients with ST-segment elevation MI (STEMI) aged 75 and older [11].
In that study, 19.6% of them died within the first year after hospital discharge [11]; in our present study, 22.6% of all patients 75 and older died during the 18-month follow-up period.
The reasons why only half of the study sample patients had contact with a cardiologist remains unclear.

Several European studies have reported inequalities in ambulatory care utilization such that persons with lower socio-economic status tend to have more GP visits, but less visits with a specialist, in comparison to persons with higher socioeconomic status [46].

In Germany, however, specialist care utilization is the highest in Europe [46,47] and one meta-analytical study showed that the relative inequality according to social status was comparatively small and became non-significant, once age and gender were controlled for [46].
Thus, socio-economic status was unrelated to specialist care seeking in Germany.

It should be noted that up until 2013, when copayments were generally waved for patients in SHI, no copayments were required for specialist care when someone had a referral from a general practitioner.
Our propensity-score matching included smoking as a coded diagnosis, which is one of the major adverse health behaviors associated with socio-economic status.

Other negative effects of social inequalities on health are entailed in the manifestation of chronic diseases and with the propensity-score matching by diagnoses, any socio-economic status differences are most likely adequately controlled for in our analyses.

Of note, in the study by Ayanian et al. [25] the difference in mortality according to with or without ambulatory cardiology care remained significant, even after controlling for patients' level of education.

This analysis supports results from US-American studies showing that the inclusion of ambulatory cardiology care in the general followup within the first year after MI diagnosis is associated with a decreased mortality risk [24].
Further research needs to clarify the mechanisms underlying this association (e.g.
increased guideline-care, increased use of diagnostic procedures in specialist care, overall management of cardiac risk factors and comorbidities).
Importantly, seeing a cardiologist alone without GP care was not associated with improved survival.
Thus, enhanced cooperation of ambulatory care cardiologists and GPs within structured networks or usage of coordinated pathways should be promoted.
Fig. 1.
Study flowchart.
MI, myocardial infarction; GP, general practitioner.
Fig. 2. Proportion of deceased patients within 18-month follow-up: results of two matched comparisons.
A) Matching I: comparison of post-myocardial infarction patients with and without cardiology care.
B) Matching II: comparison of post-myocardial infarction patients without cardiology care and those with cardiology care only (without additional contact to a GP/internist).
Characteristics of patients.
Relative risk of mortality.
None.
None.
The authors report no relationships that could be construed as a conflict of interest.
This research did not receive any specific grant from funding agencies in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https://doi.
